Amanda Visconti is a research web developer and digital humanities professor. I design, prototype, & study digital interface UX for social reading & learning, grounding my work on a strong research background (recent PhD, MS) in HCI, info science, & digital humanities and interests in annotation & user research.

Contact me to collaborate, or check out my online portfolio & resume & Twitter.

Making it public (a Knight Foundation News Challenge proposal) (Mar 24, 2016) — Humanities research and publication should be more than just writing and printing polished monographs. I envision a humanities where born-digital publication lets us document and celebrate the entire research spectrum, with all critical work (teaching, learning, discovery…) by all on... more

Better tech via annotation (using Hypothesis to improve your technical documentation, code, and tutorials) (Mar 22, 2016) — This piece originally appeared as a guest post on the Hypothes.is blog. Hypothesis makes inline annotation on any web resource possible: a visually small change from comment sections at the end of resources, but a change with a big impact.... more

Peer review for my Programming Historian lesson on Jekyll+GitHub Pages website creation (Mar 15, 2016) — I recently submitted a new digital humanities work for peer review: “Building a static website with Jekyll and GitHub Pages” at the Programming Historian.
